repositories.citation: [1] Mysten Labs. 'Seal - Decentralized Secrets Management.' GitHub, 2024-2025. https://github.com/MystenLabs/seal
key_features: Onchain access control policies using Move on Sui
Client master key derivation from single seed
repositories.architecture: Lightweight key servers enforce onchain Sui policies and provide threshold-based decryption keys. Servers are stateless, initialized with IBE master secret keys, and access trusted Sui full nodes. Multiple instances can run behind load balancers for high availability. Clients encrypt data with public keys from n servers and require t servers to respond for decryption (threshold encryption).

open.description: Single shared master key, no access restrictions

permissioned.description: Dedicated master keys per client, package allowlisting

minimum.network: Stable internet, access to Sui full node

recommended.security: Cloud KMS or HSM for master key storage
recommended.networking: API gateway with TLS termination, rate limiting
recommended.sui_node: Nearby full node for low latency

repositories.usage_example:
1. Generate master seed: `cargo run --bin seal-cli gen-seed`
2. Create config.yaml with Permissioned mode
3. Run server to discover derived public keys
4. Register on-chain: `sui client call --function create_and_transfer_v1 --module key_server`
5. Add client config with package IDs
6. Deploy with Docker: `docker-compose up -d`
7. Client integrates using @mysten/seal SDK with keyServers array

environment_variables: MASTER_KEY - Master seed for Permissioned mode (required)

limitations: Master seed compromise leads to complete system compromise
Loss of master seed = permanent loss of encrypted data access
Package IDs must use first published version (not upgraded versions)
Requires access to Sui full node for policy validation
CORS headers required for web client access
No built-in API authentication (requires external API gateway)
Stateless design means no request history tracking
security_considerations: Store master seed in enterprise-grade vault (AWS KMS, HashiCorp Vault, HSM)
Never commit master seed to version control or logs
Use TLS/SSL with valid certificates for all communications
Implement rate limiting at API gateway level
Restrict metrics endpoint to internal network only
Maintain encrypted backups in geographically distributed locations
Use hardware security modules (HSM) for production
Implement audit logging for all key derivations

documentation_sources.citation: [2] Mysten Labs. 'Seal Documentation - Key Server Operations.' Seal Docs, 2024-2025. https://seal-docs.wal.app/KeyServerOps/
coverage: Open mode deployment with complete commands

documentation_sources.citation: [3] Mysten Labs. 'Seal Mainnet Launch: Bringing Data Privacy and Access Control to Web3.' Mysten Labs Blog, 2025. https://www.mystenlabs.com/blog/seal-mainnet-launch-privacy-access-control

[4] Mysten Labs. 'Mysten Labs Launches Seal Decentralized Secrets Management on Testnet.' Mysten Labs Blog, 2024. https://www.mystenlabs.com/blog/mysten-labs-launches-seal-decentralized-secrets-management-on-testnet
[5] Mysten Labs. 'Seal | Data encryption and onchain access control.' Seal Product Page, 2025. https://seal.mystenlabs.com/
[6] Mysten Labs. '@mysten/seal - TypeScript SDK.' NPM Registry, 2024-2025. https://www.npmjs.com/package/@mysten/seal
[7] Mysten Labs. 'Seal SDK Documentation.' TypeScript SDK Docs, 2024-2025. https://sdk.mystenlabs.com/seal

common_patterns: Threshold encryption (t-of-n) is standard for production deployments
Multiple key server providers mixed for trust distribution
Stateless server architecture behind load balancers for HA
Master seed derivation for per-client isolation
Package ID allowlisting for access control
First-version package ID usage (upgrades inherit access)
Reverse proxy for TLS termination and rate limiting
best_practices: Use Permissioned mode for any production deployment
Store master seed in enterprise vault (AWS KMS, HashiCorp Vault, HSM)
Deploy minimum 3 instances for high availability
Use 2-of-3 or 3-of-5 threshold configuration for resilience
Mix key server operators across different organizations/jurisdictions
Deploy Sui full node nearby for low latency policy validation
Use API gateway for authentication, rate limiting, DDoS protection
Maintain encrypted backups of master seed in multiple locations
Test key rotation and disaster recovery procedures regularly
Document all client configurations and key derivation indices
pitfalls: Losing master seed = permanent data loss (no recovery possible)
Using Open mode in production (no access control)
Exposing key server directly without reverse proxy/TLS
Using upgraded package IDs instead of first version
Storing master seed in environment variables in config files
Committing .env files with master seeds to git
Single key server deployment (single point of failure)
Insufficient monitoring of Sui RPC connectivity
Forgetting to update server URL after transfer
Missing CORS headers causing client integration failures
emerging_trends: Integration with AI model access control
Decentralized social media with encrypted messaging
Healthcare data access control on blockchain

implementation_recommendations.scenario: Small project with 1-10 clients, moderate security requirements
implementation_recommendations.recommended_solution: Single key server in Permissioned mode with 2-of-3 threshold using 2 commercial providers + your server
implementation_recommendations.rationale: Balances operational complexity with security. Commercial providers handle HA for their nodes, you control one key share. 2-of-3 threshold tolerates one provider downtime.

implementation_recommendations.scenario: Medium project with 10-100 clients, high security requirements
implementation_recommendations.recommended_solution: 3 key server instances behind load balancer in Permissioned mode, 3-of-5 threshold with 2 self-hosted + 3 commercial providers
implementation_recommendations.rationale: High availability with geographic distribution. Can tolerate 2 provider failures. Self-hosted instances give full control. Mix of providers distributes trust.

implementation_recommendations.scenario: Enterprise with 100+ clients, compliance and regulatory requirements
implementation_recommendations.recommended_solution: Multi-region HA deployment with 5+ instances per region, 5-of-9 threshold mixing providers across jurisdictions, HSM for master seed storage
implementation_recommendations.rationale: Meets enterprise SLAs and compliance needs. Geographic diversity for regulatory compliance. HSM provides highest security. Can tolerate multiple failures.
implementation_recommendations.estimated_cost: High - 10+ servers + HSM + monitoring + multiple provider fees

implementation_recommendations.recommended_solution: Use existing Open mode testnet key servers provided by Mysten Labs and partners
implementation_recommendations.rationale: No deployment needed. Free access. No security guarantees needed for test data. Focus on building application logic first.

implementation_recommendations.recommended_solution: Deploy Permissioned mode servers on mainnet, configure threshold committee, export test data if possible or re-encrypt, update client configuration
implementation_recommendations.rationale: Testnet keys should never be used for production data. Clean migration ensures production security standards.

implementation_recommendations.scenario: Key server operator wants to exit
implementation_recommendations.recommended_solution: Export client keys, transfer key server objects to new operator, import keys on new infrastructure, coordinate URL update with clients
implementation_recommendations.rationale: Seal supports operator changes without client disruption. Key export/import mechanism enables smooth transitions.

popular_solutions: AWS KMS or HashiCorp Vault for master seed storage
Nginx or Traefik as reverse proxy
integration_examples: AI model inference with encrypted prompts
Healthcare data sharing with role-based access
expert_opinions: Threshold encryption is critical - never rely on single key server
Master seed security is paramount - use HSM for production
Test disaster recovery regularly - master seed loss is irreversible
Geographic distribution of key servers improves resilience and compliance
Client configuration should specify multiple providers for redundancy
Monitoring Sui RPC connectivity is as important as monitoring key server health
Package ID allowlisting prevents unauthorized access - audit regularly

phase_1_preparation: Set up Sui CLI and wallet with gas tokens
Choose Sui full node (self-hosted or public)
Select commercial providers for threshold committee
phase_2_key_generation: Store master seed in vault with encryption
Create encrypted backup in separate location
Set up access controls for vault
phase_3_deployment: Build Docker image from Seal repository
Create initial config.yaml with Permissioned mode
Run server to discover derived public keys
Register first key server on Sui blockchain
Deploy behind reverse proxy with TLS
phase_4_client_onboarding: Register key server object for client
Provide client with key server URL and object ID

monitoring_metrics: Server uptime and health check status
maintenance_tasks: Evaluate new SDK versions for clients

commercial_providers.benefits: No operational overhead, HA included, SLA guarantees
commercial_providers.considerations: Vendor lock-in, less control, trust assumptions

immediate: Set up Sui CLI and wallet
Decide on deployment architecture (self-hosted vs commercial)
short_term: Register on Sui testnet for testing
long_term: Document and train team on operations

research_metadata.confidence_level: High - based on official documentation and source code
